This is what DevCreek (www.devcreek.com) does, and the results are often su=
rprising. For example, we noticed that on Wednesdays the DevCreek team itse=
lf wrote a quarter of the tests it wrote on other days. Turns out they were=
 spending most of the day preparing for the weekly status meeting. Teams us=
ing DevCreek don't seem to change their behavior much on the basis of the f=
eedback, though, which I find surprising. Perhaps the feedback isn't really=
 all that useful, perhaps we don't have the right presentation of the infor=
mation, or perhaps people just need to get used to the idea that the inform=
ation is there for them.
 
Regards,
 
Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
